title: Domain 1.5: Compare and contrast transmission media and transceivers.
content:
🌐 802.11 Standards

These standards define Wi-Fi networking protocols, which are commonly used for local area network (LAN) connectivity.

Common standards: 802.11a/b/g/n/ac/ax (Wi-Fi 5 and Wi-Fi 6).

📱 Cellular

Cellular networks (3G, 4G, 5G) provide mobile data services through radio waves and are commonly used for internet access on mobile devices.

🌍 Satellite

Satellite communications use radio waves to connect remote areas to networks by transmitting signals to and from orbiting satellites.

🖥️ Wired Transmission

🌐 802.3 Standards

These standards define Ethernet protocols for wired networking, including various speeds (10 Mbps to 100 Gbps) and transmission methods.

🧵 Single-mode vs. Multimode Fiber

Single-mode fiber: Uses lasers for transmission, enabling long-distance communication with high bandwidth.

Multimode fiber: Uses LEDs and is suited for shorter distances but offers lower bandwidth than single-mode fiber.

🔌 Direct Attach Copper (DAC) Cable

A copper cable used for short-distance interconnects (within data centers or racks).

🌐 Coaxial Cable

A cable that carries signals with a central conductor, insulation, and shielding—commonly used for cable internet and TV services.

🚀 Cable Speeds

Different cable types support different data transfer speeds. For example, fiber optic cables provide significantly faster speeds than copper cables.

🏢 Plenum vs. Non-Plenum Cable

Plenum cable: Rated for installation in air ducts and other spaces with high airflow, with a fire-resistant coating.

Non-plenum cable: Not fire-rated for air ducts, often used in non-ventilated areas.

🔌 Transceivers

💻 Protocol

Ethernet: A popular protocol used for local area networks (LANs), using both copper (Cat5/6) and fiber cables for communication.

Fibre Channel (FC): A high-speed network protocol used primarily for storage area networks (SANs), offering high throughput and low latency.

🖥️ Form Factors

Small Form-Factor Pluggable (SFP): A compact transceiver used for short- and long-distance data transmission, compatible with both fiber and copper cables.

Quad Small Form-Factor Pluggable (QSFP): A larger transceiver supporting faster data rates and used in high-speed networks, often for 40 Gbps or 100 Gbps links.

🔌 Connector Types

🏷️ Subscriber Connector (SC)

A fiber optic connector used for high-performance networking, typically used in telecom networks and data centers for single-mode fiber.

🌍 Local Connector (LC)

A small form factor fiber connector commonly used in high-density applications. It's often used in data centers and telecom equipment.

📐 Straight Tip (ST)

A fiber optic connector that uses a bayonet-style twist-lock mechanism. It’s often used in older networking installations, including in Ethernet backbones.

🔗 Multi-fiber Push On (MPO)

A fiber optic connector designed to carry multiple fibers in a single connector—commonly used in high-speed data centers for dense cabling systems.

📞 Registered Jack (RJ)11

A connector commonly used for telecommunication applications, such as connecting telephones to phone lines. It typically handles voice signals.

🖥️ RJ45

The most common connector for Ethernet cables (Cat5, Cat6) in networking. It has 8 pins and is used for connecting computers, routers, and other network devices over LANs.

📡 F-type

A coaxial connector commonly used for TV cable connections and cable modems. It’s frequently used for residential broadband internet connections.

🔌 Bayonet Neill–Concelman (BNC)

A type of coaxial cable connector used for connecting video and audio equipment or legacy networking applications, especially in CCTV and RF communication.
